revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2015}}
'''Xolve, Inc.''' is a [[Madison, Wisconsin]]-based [[nanomaterial]] [[company]] that uses its proprietary technology to improve the attributes and performance of [[polymer]] composites and energy storage materials.<ref name=rc>{{cite web |url= http://research.cleantech.com/company/xolve-inc |title= Xolve Cleantech |accessdate= 5 February 2013 |work= Xolve, Inc.}}</ref><ref name=au>{{cite web |url= http://gtp.autm.net/startup/view/76 |title= Association of University Technology Managers |accessdate= 5 February 2013}}</ref> The company is known for developing a process that uses [[organic compound]]s or [[polymer]]s to either dissolve or place true [[solution]]s of [[nanoparticle]]s previously thought to be [[insoluble]], including [[carbon nanotube]]s and [[graphene]].<ref name="au"/><ref name=js>{{cite web |url= http://www.jsonline.com/business/112385284.html |title= Xolve Inc. raises $2 million |accessdate= 5 February 2013 |work= JSOnline |publisher= Milwaukee Wisconsin Journal Sentinel}}</ref><ref name=bw>{{cite web |url= http://images.businessweek.com/slideshows/20110211/america-s-most-promising-startups#slide92 |title= America's Most Promising Startups |accessdate= 5 February 2013 |work= BloombergBusinessWeek}}</ref><ref name=wsj>{{cite web |url= http://host.madison.com/business/xolve-nanotechnology-firm-moves-to-middleton/article_b5cd2034-c9e5-11e0-ab5c-001cc4c002e0.html |title= Xolve nanotechnology firm moves to Middleton |accessdate= 5 February 2013 |work= Wisconsin State Journal}}</ref>
Xolve won the Wisconsin Governor’s Business Plan Contest in 2008, and was named one of the top [[startup company|startups]] of 2008 by Businessweek.<ref name=js /><ref name=bw /><ref name=gbp>{{cite web|url=http://govsbizplancontest.com/meet-past-winners.aspx |title=Past BPC Winners |accessdate=5 February 2013 |work=Global Biz Planet |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229034001/http://govsbizplancontest.com/meet-past-winners.aspx |archivedate=February 29, 2012 }}</ref> The company was also a national finalist in the 2010 CleanTech Open San Jose, CA.<ref name=cto>{{cite web |url= http://www.cleantechopen.com/app.cgi/content/success_stories/index |title= Success Stories |accessdate= 27 October 2015 |work= The Cleantech Open}}</ref> The company originated from the fundamental research of then 17-year-old student Philip Streich and [[University of Wisconsin–Platteville|University of Wisconsin-Platteville]] [[Chemistry]] and [[Engineering Physics]] Professor James P. Hamilton and was founded by serial entrepreneurs Professor Hamilton and Eric Apfelbach as well as Philip Streich.<ref name=js />
== History == Founded in 2007 as Graphene Solutions, the firm was [[business incubator|incubated]] in the [[University of Wisconsin-Platteville|UW-Platteville]] Nanotechnology Center for Collaborative Research and Development, the NCCRD.<ref name=js /><ref name="gbp"/> Xolve licenses some of the earliest patents on graphene from Professor Hamilton's Group that date back to work done in 2006 and 2007.
In 2010, the company changed its name to Xolve and went on to raise $2 million in its first round of funding.<ref name="wsj"/> Primary investors included [[DSM (company)|DSM]], a Dutch material sciences company, and the Nordic Group of Companies in [[Baraboo, Wisconsin]].<ref name=js /><ref name="wsj"/> In 2011, the company moved to its own labs in [[Middleton, Wisconsin]].<ref name="wsj"/>
== Nanomaterials advancements == The potential of nanoparticles rests on their [[surface area]].<ref name=ng>{{cite web |url= http://www.nano.gov/nanotech-101/special |title= What's so special about the nanoscale? |accessdate= 5 February 2013 |work= National Nanotechnology Initiative}}</ref> However, practical applications of these materials have been limited by their tendency to form clumps and bundles, destroying that surface area.<ref name=js /> Beginning with its ability to place nanomaterials into true solutions, Xolve has developed additional technology to bring dispersed nanomaterials into industrial polymers and energy storage materials and keep them dispersed.<ref name=xv2>{{cite web |url= http://xolve.com/technology/fundamental-discovery |title= Xolve: A Fundamental Discovery |accessdate= 5 February 2013 |work= Xolve, Inc.}}</ref> With this technology, Xolve aims to lower the cost of producing nanomaterials, such as graphene, and to use these nanomaterials to dramatically improve the performance of industrial materials while maintaining their standard cost structure.<ref name="au"/><ref name="wsj"/>
